ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I know how to speak, read, and write Italian so much better!
italian language
You learn Italian grammar in a fast paced environment
Complex Italian grammar such as the Gerund and subjunctive tenses.

This summer course greatly improved my level of Italian and deepened my knowledge of grammar and vocabulary in the language specifically. While living in Italy, the course helped supplement the cultural immersion experience by teaching technicalities of grammar and vocabulary which host families and various other experiences could not. 3 hours a day of full immersion in Italian really propels you to fluency.
Refer to reviews of ITAL S130.
I was able to improve my Italian and work on the complexities behind Italian grammar.
I developed a new understanding of Italian culture and language in an immersive environment.
I got a much deeper understanding of Italian, a stronger vocabulary, and more fluency in speaking the language.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: It is great!
could be slightly more interactive

It would be great to spend more time actually speaking and having our speaking grammar fixed while doing so. You learn a lot from discussions and debate. Instead there was a "culture" section where we would listen to songs or read articles. The consensus from the class was that we would like to read something different (that we understand) or spend the time having planned debates/discussions.
A lot was crammed into the last week which made it stressful but the teaching was very clear.

The strengths are plentiful; the instructors really care about your input and help shape the course accordingly. Moreover, the fact that everything is conducted in Italian really makes a difference in terms of reaching fluency. Feedback received is very clear and although the textbook is expensive, it is thoroughly used throughout. The workload is very manageable and fair within the context of the summer experience. The grading is the right amount of harsh overall to push you to succeed. At times, however, there would be an exam and a composition around the same time after having had a required weekend trip. Furthermore, due to the intensive nature of the course, you must be prepared to get taught a complex facet of grammar the day before an exam or look over it in advance. I believe this is part of deal when you do a summer course like this, but sometimes the syllabus can put complex content close to the exam. Nevertheless, if you ask the professors they are more than welcome to make accommodations.
Refer to reviews of ITAL S130.

I believe that the strengths of the course included the kindness and willingness of the instructors to explain material that was not super clear. I think it also helped that the syllabus and instructors recommended that students read the material to be discussed in the following class the night before. It allowed for any confusions to be cleared up easier. 

As for weaknesses, there was not much. I do feel as if not enough time was spent some days on the more challenging grammar sections before switching over to the culture portion of the class.
The course was well structured. The grammar part of the class was clear and easy to understand. However, I feel that we could have learned more Italian phrases and sayings during the culture section.

The small class size made for a very engaging class and since we met every day and the class got to know each other very well, it was a very close-knit environment and very comfortable for language learning.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes!! Amazing to learn Italian.
yes
Of course, I really enjoyed every course in the study abroad program.

Regardless of your motives, from needing a language credit to pursuing the Italian major, this course is incredible. If you're not a seasoned student of languages you may find it challenging, but not unmanageable. The detail of language study delved into gives you an amazing understanding of Italian.
Refer to reviews of ITAL S130.

Yes. I truly believe that this class helped improve my Italian. While some of it was a slight recap of what was taught in ITAL 110/120, the brief relearning of the material helped solidify the basic foundations of the language before we began the more complex structuring of the language.
I would absolutely recommend. It's a wonderful experience to learn a language abroad, and the professors are very helpful and encouraging.
Yes, if they're interested in continuing with higher level Italian.

narratives.question_text: How will you use the knowledge and skills you learned in this course in your future endeavors?
comments: I will use my knowledge to speak Italian with others.
learn italian
When I go back to Italy hopefully soon!

Giacomo talked about L5 courses he's teaching and I'm very excited to use what he's taught in this summer course to further my study of Italian in a more advanced context. I'm very interested in Italian literature such as Boccaccio and Dante. His class really helped me converse in Italian to discuss these interests and read the texts in their original forms.

Next time I travel to Italy, I will not only be able to communicate with locals, but I will already have wonderful memories from my time in Siena. I will also be able to immerse myself in Italian literature and music in the states as a result.
